item.title: Vectorization by design
item.content:encoded:
Introduction​

Vectorization is one of the greatest tools for data manipulation I know and I am happy that R got this system out of the box. It makes computation simple and simplifies translation from formula to code.

Unfortunately I have encountered one limitation: R's vectors are not very compatible with functional programming or object-oriented programming, two paradigms I like when building libraries or applications.

Throughout this post, we will attempt to construct a concept of a 2D geometric point. A point is a mathematical object that has x and y coordinates. We will use the S3 system for illustration.

Vectorization with R​

As I said, R makes it pretty easy to vectorize primitive types like integers or characters.

# building a vector
v <- c(1, 2, 3, 4)

# Now we can multiply with a number or add a number

3*v + 4
#[1]  7 10 13 16

But what happens if we define a Point type?

# Point type creation
Point <- function(x, y) {
  structure(
    list(x = x, y = y),
    class = "Point"
  )
}

We will also define a print method to make them easier to visualize.

print.Point <- function(p, ...) {
  cat("Point<", p$x, ",", p$y, ">\n", sep="")
  invisible(p)
}

So we have our Point type!

Point(3, 4)
#Point<3,4>

And we will define a scale method to scale a point with a number.

scale.Point <- function(p, n) {
	Point(p$x*n, p$y*n)
}

It's now functional!

# we can use it this way
scale(Point(3, 4), 2)
#Point<6,8>

# or this way
Point(3, 4) |> scale(2)
#Point<6,8>

A little bonus: you can also supercharge the * operator for the Point class so you can scale using multiplication with a number.

`*.Point` <- function(p, n) {
	scale(p, n)
}

# Now this works
Point(3, 4) * 2
#Point<6,8>

# But the other way around doesn't work
2 * Point(3, 4)
#Point<6,8>

But what if we want a vector of types?

points <- c(Point(1, 2), 
			Point(3, 4), 
			Point(5, 6))

points

#$x
#[1] 1
#
#$y
#[1] 2
#
#$x
#[1] 3
#
#$y
#[1] 4
#
#$x
#[1] 5
#
#$y
#[1] 6

The vector of points loses its structure!

We can no longer access it easily:

points$x
#[1] 1

points$y
#[1] 2

points[1]
#$x
#[1] 1

You have to store them in a list.


points <- list(Point(1, 2), 
			Point(3, 4), 
			Point(5, 6))


points
#[[1]]
#Point<1,2>
#
#[[2]]
#Point<3,4>
#
#[[3]]
#Point<5,6>

But we aren't keeping the capability of using native vectorial operations.

# works well
points[[1]]
#Point<1,2>

points$x
#NULL

points$y
#NULL

scale(points, 2)
#Error

It's better to directly use vectors inside an S3 object but you have to do some gymnastics.

Because of that, developers should keep in mind they should manually apply vectorization while building functions for objects or functions (which is a mental load by itself).

What about TypR?​

I'm glad you asked!

TypR uses its own vectorization system named lifting-based vectorization. This concept exploits the type system of TypR to infer when to apply vectorization.

The best way to use vectorization is not to think about vectorization.

The developer just has to write their functions for scalar values and TypR will decide when to lift the parameters and the function into a vectorial computation. It's also compatible with more complex types like named lists or functions.

Let's build our Point type with a constructor:

# Type definition
type Point <- {
	x: int,
	y: int
};

# Constructor
let new_point <- fn(x: int, y: int): Point {
	list(x = x, y = y)
};

We will also define a print function for points:

# print function
let print <- fn(p: Point): Empty {
  cat("Point<", p$x, ",", p$y, ">", sep="");
  invisible(p);
};

Now we can build a point like before:

new_point(3, 4)
# Point<3,4>

We won't forget to implement the scale function.

let scale <- fn(p: Point, n: int): Point {
	new_point(p$x * n, p$y * n)
};

new_point(3, 4) 
	|> scale(2)
# Point<6,8>

Of course, we also have the capability of implementing the * operator:

let `*` <- fn(p: Point, n: int): Point {
	scale(p, n)
};

new_point(3, 4) * 2
# Point<6,8>

Now what about vectors? TypR has its own way to deal with them. Let's make a vector of points:

points <- [new_point(1, 2), 
			new_point(3, 4), 
			new_point(5, 6)]

points
#typed_vec [3]
#[1] Point<1,2>
#[2] Point<3,4>
#[3] Point<5,6>

We have an array notation like other programming languages. This kind of array automatically exploits the print function for its members.

What's the best part? TypR's arrays are vectorizable by default! So these operations work:

scale(points, 2)
#typed_vec [3]
#[1] Point<2,4>
#[2] Point<6,8>
#[3] Point<10,12>

points 
	|> scale([1, 2, 3])
#typed_vec [3]
#[1] Point<1,2>
#[2] Point<6,8>
#[3] Point<15,18>

points * 3
#typed_vec [3]
#[1] Point<3,6>
#[2] Point<9,12>
#[3] Point<15,18>

We also have the possibility to work with types by themselves. Let's define the + operator:

let `+` <- fn(p1: Point, p2: Point): Point {
	new_point(p1$x + p2$x, p1$y + p2$y)
};

# addition with a scalar
points + new_point(1, 1)
#typed_vec [3]
#[1] Point<2,3>
#[2] Point<4,5>
#[3] Point<6,7>

# addition with a vector of similar type
points + points
#typed_vec [3]
#[1] Point<2,4>
#[2] Point<6,8>
#[3] Point<10,12>

What about reduction? One can use the reduce function to reduce the elements of the array.

reduce(points, `+`<Point>)
#Point<9,12>

We specify the type <Point> for the + because TypR's type system isn't doing this kind of inference yet. But as you can see, it summed all elements of points. One can also use a shortcut and use the sum function:

points
	|> sum()
#Point<9,12>

It automatically uses the + operator underneath. If your type implements it, sum will work on the vector.

And for functions? We can also do function composition powered by vectors. I won't present examples there but later in another publication.

Future works​

I would like to create vectorized field accessors to make it easier to work with a vector of named lists:

# will give all the values contained in the x field of each point
points$x
# will give all the values contained in the y field of each point
points$y

It would also be cool to be able to call similar functions with the same parameters.


# vector of functions
let functions <- [`+`, `*`];

functions(3, 4)
# could return:
#typed_vec [3]
#[1] 7
#[2] 12

It could help with applying a set of statistical models to a specific set of data.

Conclusion​

Even though lifting-based vectorization looks like reinventing the wheel, I truly believe it's a true conceptual heir of the classic vectorization and a logical continuation of it if R was a typed language.

item.title: TypR's new official documentation
item.description: After some adventures, the official documentation will soon be open.
item.content:encoded:
After some adventures, the official documentation will soon be open.

Documentation is sometimes hard to maintain because it is an independent entity to the code base. It's even created in a separate github repository.
